A NATIONAL PORTRAIT OF RESTORATIVE JUSTICE RESPONSES TO INTIMATE PARTNER VIOLENCE

THE VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA) OF 2005 REQUIRES THAT GRANTEES REPORT ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THEIR VAWA-FUNDED PROGRAMS TO THE ATTORNEY GENERAL, WHO, IN TURN, MUST REPORT TO CONGRESS EVERY TWO YEARS ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF GRANT-FUNDED ACTIVITIES (P.L. NO. 106-386, SECTION 1003, CODIFIED AT 34 U.S.C. § 10238). SOME OVW GRANT PROGRAMS ALSO HAVE SPECIFIC REPORTING REQUIREMENTS AS OUTLINED IN THEIR RESPECTIVE AUTHORIZING LEGISLATION. IN RESPONSE TO THESE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS, OVW DEVELOPED ANNUAL AND SEMI-ANNUAL PERFORMANCE REPORTING FORMS FOR EACH OVW GRANT PROGRAM THAT TRACK GRANT-FUNDED ACTIVITIES AND INCORPORATE MEASURES TIED TO PROGRAM OBJECTIVES. GRANTEES FUNDED BY OVW REPORT CONSISTENT, QUANTITATIVE DATA THAT CAN BE AGGREGATED TO REFLECT THE ACCOMPLISHMENTS WITHIN AND ACROSS GRANT PROGRAMS. THE REPORTING FORMS ALSO COLLECT QUALITATIVE INFORMATION ON GRANTEES’ GOALS, OBJECTIVES, ACTIVITIES, ACCOMPLISHMENTS, AND REMAINING AREAS OF NEED. OVW USES THE INFORMATION COLLECTED THROUGH THESE PERFORMANCE REPORTS IN DIFFERENT WAYS, INCLUDING: MONITORING GRANT ACTIVITIES, SPOTTING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDS, PROVIDING INFORMATION TO A RANGE OF STAKEHOLDERS ON WHAT HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED WITH GRANT FUNDS, IDENTIFYING PROMISING PRACTICES, MEETING REPORTING OBLIGATIONS UNDER THE GOVERNMENT PERFORMANCE AND RESULTS ACT (GPRA) AND SUBSEQUENT LEGISLATION, RESPONDING TO THE DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE’S DATA REQUESTS RELATED TO PERFORMANCE AND BUDGET, REPORTING TO CONGRESS, AND RESPONDING TO AD HOC DATA REQUESTS FROM WITHIN AND OUTSIDE GOVERNMENT.

TO SUPPORT OVW’S FULFILMENT OF THESE DUTIES AND OBLIGATIONS, OVW ADMINISTERS THE VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA) MEASURING EFFECTIVENESS INITIATIVE (MEI) PRINCIPALLY TO SUPPORT GRANTEES IN MEASURING AND REPORTING INFORMATION ON THEIR VAWA-FUNDED ACTIVITIES. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT THE FIRST 18 MONTHS OF A FIVE-YEAR PROJECT WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN MAINE (USM)’S MUSKIE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC SERVICE TO CONTINUE AND ENHANCE THE MEI. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: REVIEWING, CLEANING, AND ANALYZING DATA COLLECTED FROM GRANTEE PERFORMANCE REPORTS; MAINTAINING THAT INFORMATION IN A DATABASE; WORKING IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OVW TO FULFILL REPORTING REQUIREMENTS; RESPONDING TO DATA REQUESTS; PROVIDING ONGOING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OVW GRANTEES ON COLLECTING DATA TO ASSESS THEIR OWN PERFORMANCE AND ACCURATELY COMPLETING THEIR PERFORMANCE REPORTS; ASSISTING OVW IN THE PREPARATION OF REPORTS TO CONGRESS AND ADDITIONAL MATERIALS AND ANALYSES RELATED TO VAWA-FUNDED ACTIVITIES; KEEPING ABREAST OF NEWLY PUBLISHED RESEARCH AND DATA RELATED TO GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE AND INCORPORATING THAT INFORMATION INTO REPORTS AND OTHER MATERIALS; AND CREATING TOOLS TO FACILITATE PERFORMANCE DATA COLLECTION, REPORTING, AND ANALYSIS BY FORMULA PROGRAM GRANTEES AND SUBGRANTEES.

THE TIMING FOR PERFORMANCE OF THIS INITIAL AWARD IS 18 MONTHS.

THE RESEARCH AND EVALUATION (R&E) INITIATIVE IS AUTHORIZED BY 34 USC 12291(B)(7), WHICH PERMITS OVW TO SET ASIDE UP TO THREE PERCENT OF AVAILABLE FUNDS FROM MOST OVW PROGRAMS TO CONDUCT EVALUATIONS OF PROMISING PRACTICES FOR COMBATTING DOMESTIC/DATING VIOLENCE, SEXUAL ASSAULT, AND STALKING, AND TO RESEARCH PROBLEMS EMERGING IN THE FIELD. BY GENERATING MORE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT STRATEGIES FOR SERVING VICTIMS AND HOLDING OFFENDERS ACCOUNTABLE, COMMUNITIES THAT BENEFIT FROM VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA) FUNDING WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO ALIGN THEIR WORK WITH PRACTICES THAT ARE KNOWN TO BE EFFECTIVE, AND THEY WILL BE MORE CAPABLE OF BUILDING EMPIRICAL KNOWLEDGE ON THE EFFICACY OF NEW AND PROMISING WAYS OF MAKING COMMUNITIES SAFER AND MORE JUST.

THIS AWARD PROVIDES SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING TO THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH DAKOTA TO SUPPORT THE FINAL 24 MONTHS OF A THREE-YEAR PROJECT FOR WHICH THE INITIAL 12 MONTHS OF FUNDING WAS PROVIDED IN FY 2021. THE STUDY INVOLVES INDIGENOUS-LED RESEARCH ON SEX TRAFFICKING VICTIMIZATION AMONG NATIVE AMERICANS IN WESTERN SOUTH DAKOTA. THE AWARD NUMBER FOR THIS PROJECT'S INITIAL FUNDING IS 15JOVW-21-GG-02482-MUMU.

THIS PROJECT WITH TEMPLE UNIVERSITY INVOLVES AN EVALUATION OF THE INDEPENDENCE PROJECT, AN INNOVATIVE ECONOMIC EMPOWERMENT PROGRAM ESTABLISHED BY THE NATIONAL NETWORK TO END DOMESTIC VIOLENCE (NNEDV) TO ASSIST SURVIVORS OF INTIMATE PARTNER VIOLENCE WITH IMPROVING THEIR CREDIT SCORES THROUGH MICRO-LENDING. THE STUDY WILL ASSESS THE EFFICACY AND IMPACT OF THE INDEPENDENCE PROJECT ON IMPROVING SURVIVORS’ FINANCIAL SECURITY, PSYCHOLOGICAL WELLBEING, AND SAFETY. IT WILL USE A MIXED-METHODS, LONGITUDINAL DESIGN. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL PRODUCE A FINAL RESEARCH REPORT, PRESENTATIONS AT ACADEMIC CONFERENCES, A MINIMUM OF THREE PEER-REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS, AND A WEBINAR AND RESEARCH BRIEF INTENDED FOR SERVICE PROVIDERS.

THIS AWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE PROVIDES SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING FOR THE FINAL 12 MONTHS OF A THREE-YEAR PROJECT FOR WHICH THE INITIAL 24 MONTHS OF FUNDING WAS PROVIDED IN FY 2021. THE STUDY IS AN EVALUATION OF A RAPE CRISIS CENTER’S ECONOMIC CASE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. THE INITIAL FUNDING WAS PROVIDED UNDER AWARD NUMBER 15JOVW-21-GG-02487-MUMU.

THIS PROJECT WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS IS AN OUTCOME EVALUATION OF THE PATIENT EXPERIENCE WITH IN-PERSON SEXUAL ASSAULT NURSE EXAMINER (SANE) AND TELESANE (I.E., SANE CARE PROVIDED VIA TELEHEALTH TECHNOLOGY) CARE. RESEARCHERS WORKING IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A WELL-ESTABLISHED SANE PROGRAM WILL INTERVIEW PATIENTS WHO RECEIVED IN-PERSON AND TELEHEALTH CARE AND USE INTERVIEW FINDINGS TO GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND PILOT TESTING A PATIENT EXPERIENCE ASSESSMENT TOOL (PEAT) THAT IN-PERSON SANE AND TELESANE PROGRAMS CAN USE FOR ONGOING MONITORING AND IMPROVEMENT. INTERVIEW PARTICIPANTS FROM THE FIRST PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL BE INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE PEAT, THE ANALYSIS OF THE PILOT FINDINGS, AND A REVIEW OF THE PEAT BEFORE IT IS FINALIZED. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE SIGNIFICANTLY TO IN-PERSON SANE AND TELESANE PROGRAMS’ ABILITY TO IMPROVE THEIR PATIENTS’ EXPERIENCES BY CONDUCTING THE FIRST-EVER QUALITATIVE PATIENT EXPERIENCE INTERVIEWS WITH TELESANE PATIENTS, COMPARING THE EXPERIENCES OF IN-PERSON SANE AND TELESANE PATIENTS, AND DEVELOPING A PEAT AND SUPPORTING GUIDES THAT CAN BE WIDELY ADOPTED BY PROGRAMS PROVIDING POST-ASSAULT MEDICAL FORENSIC CARE. 

EVALUATION FINDINGS WILL BE SHARED WITH STATE AND NATIONAL PRACTITIONERS AND POLICYMAKERS TO INFORM THE EXPANSION OF IN-PERSON SANE AND TELESANE SERVICES. THE FINAL PEAT AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE FOR SANE/TELESANE PROGRAMS TO USE FREELY. FINDINGS WILL ALSO BE SHARED VIA PRACTITIONER-ORIENTED AND MEDIA OUTLETS AND PRESENTED AT ACADEMIC CONFERENCES AND IN PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS.

THE RESEARCH AND EVALUATION (R&E) INITIATIVE IS AUTHORIZED BY 34 USC 12291(B)(7), WHICH PERMITS OVW TO SET ASIDE UP TO THREE PERCENT OF AVAILABLE FUNDS FROM MOST OVW PROGRAMS TO CONDUCT EVALUATIONS OF PROMISING PRACTICES FOR COMBATTING DOMESTIC/DATING VIOLENCE, SEXUAL ASSAULT, AND STALKING, AND TO RESEARCH PROBLEMS EMERGING IN THE FIELD. GROUNDED IN TRAUMA-INFORMED PRINCIPLES, THIS PROJECT WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS WILL INVOLVE AN ITERATIVE, USER-CENTERED DESIGN PROCESS TO DEVELOP AND THEN EMBED INFORMATION AND TAILORED RESOURCES RELATED TO GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE (GBV) WITHIN A SMARTPHONE APPLICATION THAT STUDENTS ALREADY USE TO NAVIGATE CAMPUS LIFE (THE ILLINOIS APP). A DIVERSE STUDENT GROUP WILL INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE NEW GBV CAPABILITY FOR THE APP, WHICH WILL INCLUDE TOOLS AND SELF-ASSESSMENTS FOR SAFETY PLANNING, OPTIONS FOR WHERE AND HOW TO REPORT, CAMPUS AND COMMUNITY RESOURCES, AND INFORMATION ON EVENTS THAT ARE LIKELY TO ENSUE AFTER CHOOSING TO REPORT. A RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL WILL EXAMINE THE DEGREE TO WHICH THIS GBV CAPABILITY FOSTERS PERCEIVED EMPOWERMENT, SAFETY STRATEGIES, AND KNOWLEDGE OF RESOURCES AND HELP-SEEKING AND REPORTING BEHAVIORS.

THIS AWARD SUPPLIES SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING TO NORTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY FOR THE FINAL 24 MONTHS OF A STUDY FOR WHICH THE FIRST 12 MONTHS WERE FUNDED IN FY 2021. THE STUDY EXAMINES A SPECIALIZED DOMESTIC VIOLENCE COURT AND ASSOCIATIONS AMONG VICTIM ADVOCACY, SURVIVOR PARTICIPATION, AND SURVIVOR OUTCOMES. THE AWARD NUMBER FOR THE GRANT THAT THIS SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING RELATES TO IS 15JOVW-21-GG-02486-ICJR.

THE RESEARCH AND EVALUATION (R&E) INITIATIVE IS AUTHORIZED BY 34 USC 12291(B)(7), WHICH PERMITS OVW TO SET ASIDE UP TO THREE PERCENT OF AVAILABLE FUNDS FROM MOST OVW PROGRAMS TO CONDUCT EVALUATIONS OF PROMISING PRACTICES FOR COMBATTING DOMESTIC/DATING VIOLENCE, SEXUAL ASSAULT, AND STALKING, AND TO RESEARCH PROBLEMS EMERGING IN THE FIELD. BY GENERATING MORE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT STRATEGIES FOR SERVING VICTIMS AND HOLDING OFFENDERS ACCOUNTABLE, COMMUNITIES THAT BENEFIT FROM VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA) FUNDING WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO ALIGN THEIR WORK WITH PRACTICES THAT ARE KNOWN TO BE EFFECTIVE, AND THEY WILL BE MORE CAPABLE OF BUILDING EMPIRICAL KNOWLEDGE ON THE EFFICACY OF NEW AND PROMISING WAYS OF MAKING COMMUNITIES SAFER AND MORE JUST.

RECOGNIZING THAT THERE IS A PRESSING NEED TO UNDERSTAND SEXUAL ASSAULT SURVIVORS’ PERCEPTIONS OF HELPFUL AND UNHELPFUL ASPECTS OF THEIR EXPERIENCES SEEKING CIVIL NO CONTACT ORDERS (CNCOS), AND FOCUSING ON THE ROLE OF ADVOCATES AND LAWYERS AND SURVIVOR AND COMMUNITY DIVERSITY, THIS STUDY WITH DEPAUL UNIVERSITY WILL INVOLVE QUALITATIVE INTERVIEWS WILL BE CONDUCTED WITH 45-50 ADULT SURVIVORS WHO SOUGHT A CNCO AND SOUGHT HELP FROM ONE OF THE FOCAL RAPE CRISIS CENTERS. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A STATE SEXUAL ASSAULT COALITION, THE RESEARCHERS WILL INTERVIEW 30-35 URBAN SURVIVORS (AT LEAST 10 BLACK AND AT LEAST 10 LATINO/A/X SURVIVORS), 15-20 RURAL SURVIVORS, AND 15 SURVIVORS WHO DID AND 15 WHO DID NOT SPEAK WITH A LAWYER ABOUT THEIR CNCO. THIS STUDY WILL CONTRIBUTE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE UNIQUE EXPERIENCES OF SEXUAL ASSAULT SURVIVORS WHO SEEK CNCOS OUTSIDE THE CONTEXT OF DOMESTIC/DATING VIOLENCE. FINDINGS WILL BE SHARED WITH STATE AND NATIONAL STAKEHOLDER GROUPS REPRESENTING VICTIM ADVOCATES, JUDGES, AND LAWYERS VIA PRACTITIONER REPORTS, PRESENTATIONS, AND A PRACTITIONER-ORIENTED CONFERENCE. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL PRESENT AT TWO SCHOLARLY CONFERENCES AND SUBMIT AT LEAST TWO MANUSCRIPTS TO PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS.

THE RESEARCH AND EVALUATION (R&E) INITIATIVE IS AUTHORIZED BY 34 USC 12291(B)(7), WHICH PERMITS OVW TO SET ASIDE UP TO THREE PERCENT OF AVAILABLE FUNDS FROM MOST OVW PROGRAMS TO CONDUCT EVALUATIONS OF PROMISING PRACTICES FOR COMBATTING DOMESTIC/DATING VIOLENCE, SEXUAL ASSAULT, AND STALKING, AND TO RESEARCH PROBLEMS EMERGING IN THE FIELD. BY GENERATING MORE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT STRATEGIES FOR SERVING VICTIMS AND HOLDING OFFENDERS ACCOUNTABLE, COMMUNITIES THAT BENEFIT FROM VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA) FUNDING WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO ALIGN THEIR WORK WITH PRACTICES THAT ARE KNOWN TO BE EFFECTIVE, AND THEY WILL BE MORE CAPABLE OF BUILDING EMPIRICAL KNOWLEDGE ON THE EFFICACY OF NEW AND PROMISING WAYS OF MAKING COMMUNITIES SAFER AND MORE JUST.

THIS STUDY WITH IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY BUILDS OFF OF PROMISING FINDINGS FROM EARLIER OVW-FUNDED RESEARCH ON A RELATIONSHIP VIOLENCE INTERVENTION PROGRAM (RVIP) CALLED ACHIEVING CHANGE THROUGH VALUES-BASED BEHAVIOR (ACTV), WHICH USES A COGNITIVE BEHAVIORAL APPROACH. NOTING THAT RVIPS HAVE GENERALLY BEEN FOUND TO HAVE LITTLE IMPACT ON DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, AND RVIPS MAY CAUSE MORE HARM FOR MEN OF COLOR DUE TO HIGHER DROPOUT RATES, THE RESEARCH TEAM AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS RECOGNIZED A NEED FOR CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE RVIP FOR MEN OF COLOR AND, THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED PARTICIPATORY RESEARCH, CREATED A NEW RVIP CALLED PROACTIVE, WHICH IS BASED ON ACTV. PARTICIPANTS IN THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL BE 90 MEN OF COLOR WHO HAVE RECENTLY ENGAGED IN INTIMATE PARTNER VIOLENCE (IPV) AND VOLUNTARILY TAKE PART IN THE 12-WEEK PROGRAM. DATA WILL EXAMINE THE INITIAL EFFECTIVENESS, FEASIBILITY AND ACCEPTABILITY OF PROACTIVE, INCLUDING PARTICIPANT RETENTION, REPORTS OF WORKING ALLIANCE (A FEATURE OF AN EFFECTIVE THERAPEUTIC RELATIONSHIP), AND ANY CHANGES IN PARTICIPANTS’ SELF-REPORTED IPV BEHAVIORS. RESEARCH ON THIS ADAPTED RVIP MODEL, WHICH WAS CREATED COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE COMMUNITY WHERE IT IS IMPLEMENTED, WILL CONTRIBUTE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT NON-CARCERAL AND CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE STRATEGIES FOR REDUCING IPV.

THE RESEARCH AND EVALUATION (R&E) INITIATIVE IS AUTHORIZED BY 34 USC 12291(B)(7), WHICH PERMITS OVW TO SET ASIDE UP TO THREE PERCENT OF AVAILABLE FUNDS FROM MOST OVW PROGRAMS TO CONDUCT EVALUATIONS OF PROMISING PRACTICES FOR COMBATTING DOMESTIC/DATING VIOLENCE, SEXUAL ASSAULT, AND STALKING, AND TO RESEARCH PROBLEMS EMERGING IN THE FIELD. BY GENERATING MORE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT STRATEGIES FOR SERVING VICTIMS AND HOLDING OFFENDERS ACCOUNTABLE, COMMUNITIES THAT BENEFIT FROM VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA) FUNDING WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO ALIGN THEIR WORK WITH PRACTICES THAT ARE KNOWN TO BE EFFECTIVE, AND THEY WILL BE MORE CAPABLE OF BUILDING EMPIRICAL KNOWLEDGE ON THE EFFICACY OF NEW AND PROMISING WAYS OF MAKING COMMUNITIES SAFER AND MORE JUST.

THIS PROJECT WITH YALE UNIVERSITY DRAWS FROM RESEARCH OUTSIDE OF THE GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE FIELD THAT TARGETS HOPE AS AN OUTCOME FOR INTERVENTIONS, SINCE HOPE MAY HELP PREDICT OTHER, POSITIVE LONG-TERM OUTCOMES. THE PROJECT TEAM, WHICH INCLUDES DOMESTIC VIOLENCE SURVIVORS, WILL DEVELOP AN INTERVENTION TO INCREASE SURVIVORS’ SENSE OF HOPE, AND, IN TURN, THEIR SELF-WORTH, EMPOWERMENT, AND EMOTIONAL WELL-BEING. PILOT TESTING WILL ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY, ACCEPTABILITY, AND SAFETY OF THE INTERVENTION. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS A NEED FOR LOW-BURDEN INTERVENTIONS FOR SURVIVORS WHO HAVE NO INTENTION OF SEEKING SERVICES AT BRICK-AND-MORTAR PROGRAMS, AND THE STUDY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A BURGEONING BODY OF RESEARCH ON THE ROLE OF HOPE IN SURVIVORS’ RECOVERY. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN: 1) REPORTS TO OVW, 2) A WEB-BASED SINGLE-SESSION INTERVENTION TARGETING HOPE; 3) PROCESS EVALUATION FINDINGS; INTERVENTION EFFICACY FINDINGS; AND A DESCRIPTION OF THE DYNAMIC NATURE OF HOPE; 4) AT LEAST SIX PRACTITIONER AND SCHOLARLY PRODUCTS, AND 5) ARCHIVABLE DATA.

THE RESEARCH AND EVALUATION (R&E) INITIATIVE IS AUTHORIZED BY 34 USC 12291(B)(7), WHICH PERMITS OVW TO SET ASIDE UP TO THREE PERCENT OF AVAILABLE FUNDS FROM MOST OVW PROGRAMS TO CONDUCT EVALUATIONS OF PROMISING PRACTICES FOR COMBATTING DOMESTIC/DATING VIOLENCE, SEXUAL ASSAULT, AND STALKING, AND TO RESEARCH PROBLEMS EMERGING IN THE FIELD. BY GENERATING MORE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT STRATEGIES FOR SERVING VICTIMS AND HOLDING OFFENDERS ACCOUNTABLE, COMMUNITIES THAT BENEFIT FROM VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA) FUNDING WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO ALIGN THEIR WORK WITH PRACTICES THAT ARE KNOWN TO BE EFFECTIVE, AND THEY WILL BE MORE CAPABLE OF BUILDING EMPIRICAL KNOWLEDGE ON THE EFFICACY OF NEW AND PROMISING WAYS OF MAKING COMMUNITIES SAFER AND MORE JUST.

THIS MIXED-METHODS LONGITUDINAL EVALUATION OF SURVIVORS’ EXPERIENCES WITH A DOMESTIC VIOLENCE COURT WILL INVOLVE A SAMPLE OF 250 SURVIVORS TO EXAMINE THE ASSOCIATIONS BETWEEN SURVIVORS’ ENGAGEMENT IN, AND PERCEPTIONS OF, COURT-BASED SERVICES, AS WELL AS OUTCOMES RELATED TO: A) REDUCED REVICTIMIZATION; B) MENTAL HEALTH AND WELL-BEING; C) SAFETY AND EMPOWERMENT; AND D) WILLINGNESS TO ENGAGE WITH THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM IN THE FUTURE. THE PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE ONGOING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE CENTER FOR THE STUDY OF FAMILY VIOLENCE AND SEXUAL ASSAULT AT NORTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY AND WINNEBAGO COUNTY (ILLINOIS)’S DOMESTIC VIOLENCE COORDINATED COURT (DVCC).

THE INITIAL PERFORMANCE PERIOD FOR THIS PROJECT IS 12 MONTHS. OVW ANTICIPATES SUPPLEMENTING THIS AWARD IN FY 2022 SO THAT THE STUDY IS FUNDED AT THE REQUESTED AMOUNT, FOR THE FULL 36-MONTH DURATION. SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING IS CONTINGENT ON AVAILABLE FUNDING AND OTHER FACTORS.
